unnormalised: Okay, so you want a loan? Buckle up, bhaiyo aur behno, because it’s a wild ride, steeper than the ghat roads near Lonavala! Securing a loan is like trying to find a decent parking spot in Chandni Chowk on Diwali – improbable, stressful, and you'll probably end up paying more than you initially intended.

unnormalised: First, you gotta navigate the bureaucratic jungle. Think of it as the government's version of an escape room, except instead of fun puzzles, you get forms. So. Many. Forms. You'll need your PAN card, Aadhar card, voter ID, your great-grandmother's birth certificate, and possibly a blood sample just to prove you're a real person and not some elaborate AI bot trying to game the system. Each document must be attested by a gazetted officer, which, let's be honest, sounds like something out of a fantasy novel.

You'll need your P-A-N card, Aadhar card, voter I-D, your great-grandmother's birth certificate, and possibly a blood sample just to prove you're a real person and not some elaborate A-I bot trying to game the system. Each document must be attested by a gazetted officer, which, let's be honest, sounds like something out of a fantasy novel.

unnormalised: Then there's the interest rate. You see the advertisements promising "Attractive rates starting from just 7.5%!" Sounds amazing, right? Just remember, "starting from" is the key phrase here. By the time you factor in processing fees, hidden charges, and the loan officer's insistence on explaining compound interest using a complicated flowchart, you're probably closer to paying 14.5%. They might as well just tell you upfront that you're signing away your chai-samosa budget for the next 5 yrs.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on the collateral. They want something substantial. Your family home? Your prized vintage scooter? Your collection of Bollywood movie posters? Banks are like that karkhana owner, "arre bhai, guarantee toh chahiye." If you're thinking of using your gold jewelry, prepare for a thorough appraisal. They'll examine each bangle and necklace with the intensity of a forensic scientist, probably muttering things like "Is this 22K or just gold-plated?" You'll be sitting there sweating, hoping they don't notice that one earring you accidentally bent while dancing at your cousin's wedding.

unnormalised: Now, let's talk repayments. The EMI. The dreaded Equated Monthly Installment. This little beast will stalk you like a shadow, reminding you month after month of your financial woes. It’s like that annoying relative who always shows up uninvited to family gatherings, except instead of eating all the jalebis, it eats your salary. And God forbid you miss an EMI payment. Late fees will pile up faster than the garbage on a Kolkata street corner during Durga Puja.

unnormalised: Then there are the pre-payment penalties. You get a bonus at work? You think, "Awesome, I'll pay off some of the loan!" Nope. The bank will slap you with a pre-payment penalty, because apparently, they're upset that you're trying to give them money early. It's like they're saying, "How dare you try to escape our perfectly crafted system of financial servitude!" Seriously, sometimes you wonder if they're intentionally making it hard to pay off loans, just so they can keep milking you for every last rupee.

Just remember to read the fine print (with a magnifying glass, preferably), ask a million questions (even the ones that seem stupid), and maybe consider selling your prized possessions on Olx before resorting to a loan. At least that way, you'll get to keep your sanity, your family home, and your peace of mind. Maybe. But hey, at least you'll have some extra cash for some good chai and pakoras!
